comment.text: No issues noted on Ivy Bridge x86_64 and Diamondville i686.

A word of caution if you are using the mpt2sas driver and are upgrading from kernel-4.3 to kernel-4.4, you may need to add dracut options and regenerate your initramfs before rebooting since mtt2sas has been merged into mpt3sas: https://lkml.org/lkml/2016/1/8/693
Works with ThinkPad T530
Works here on x86_64 and i686.
LGTM, Thinkpad X250 (Broadwell)

I used to be able to hit Esc after issuing a reboot or shutdown command (and getting logged out) and check system messages before the command completed; I can no longer do that with 4.4 kernels. Is there a setting that can be tweaked someplace?
Tested on Broadwell i7 laptop and i3 desktop. Everything seems to work just fine so far. ;)

I get "md127: Warning: Device sdc2 is misaligned" for all RAID partitions which are connected to a USB3 caddy holding 2 SATA drives. This makes my RAIDs unusable.

It eventually results in for example (log starts at the bottom first):
Mar 02 00:55:03 larry kernel: sd 2:0:0:1: [sdc] tag#27 CDB: Read(10) 28 00 3b a0 55 e0 00 00 08 00

Mar 02 00:54:22 larry kernel: sd 2:0:0:1: [sdc] tag#31 CDB: Read(10) 28 00 36 e0 4b 00 00 00 08 00
Mar 02 00:54:22 larry kernel: sd 2:0:0:1: [sdc] tag#31 uas_eh_abort_handler 0 uas-tag 32 inflight: CMD IN

This happens with both 4.4 kernels tried. 4.3.5-300.fc23.x86_64 causes no problems
Boot fails (actually graphical GNOME login, terminal login is OK) with this kernel on my laptop with Intel Corporation Broadwell-U Integrated Graphics.
Works for me. Tested on server Supermicro X8DAH with cpu Intel Xeon X5680 and Supermicro X10DRi wit cpu Intel Xeon E5-2690 v3, and pc Fujitsu ESPRIMO P920 with cpu Intel i7-4770.
everything is checking out

Please see:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1295646#c7


karma: -1

Bug: javafx applications are with an increasing consumption of RAM, until the fedora mate execution itself, locking the system. Tests with the controlsfx-sample and the Ensemble8.jar (demo package of demos and examples of jdk). With version 4.2 and 4.3 of the kernel does not happen this problem.
PS: Tests with: java version "1.8.0_74" Java (TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_74-b02)

bugs.title: test kernel-4.4.2-300.fc23.x86_64 disk partition mount bug

bugzilla.short_desc: test kernel-4.4.2-300.fc23.x86_64 disk partition mount bug

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem: Tried new test kernel. All hard drive partitions are mounted on boot on Mate desktop instead of just the boot partition, an incorrect action which also bypasses security measures. Mouse menu shows "eject", not "unmount", and partitions can't be unmounted.


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):kernel-4.4.2-300.fc23.x86_64


How reproducible: boot into Mate desktop.


Steps to Reproduce:
1.normal boot with new test kernel.
2.
3.

Actual results:Bugs per description.


Expected results: Only boot partition mounted at startup.


Additional info:

Can you confirm if you go back to an older kernel version the partitions are shown/not shown as appropriate?

Was the kernel the only package you updated with this?

Are you referring to specific security measures that this violates or just general security practices?

Can you also share your system logs (all of journalctl) from a bootup with the non-working kernel?

I performed a routine update that included many packages besides the test kernel. List follows here. Currently running 4.3.5-300.fc23.x86_64 which works correctly (with all other updates still applied). By security, I mean partitions mounted automatically on boot instead of needing root permissions to mount individually (no hard drive partitions are configured to auto-mount)

I'll try to get journalctl for you.

udisksctl dump outputs tell the story. Kdiff3 shows a slew of differences, starting with /dev/sda HintAuto false for working, and true for nonworking.

Hintsystem true for working, false for nonworking.

empty mountpoint for MSDOS partition on mounting, MountPoints:        /run/media/Bob/MSDOS for non-working (obvious problem).

Long list of similar discrepancies.

so based on the output of udisksctl, it looks like something thinks that the drive is removable which generates the rules as given.  I looked through the kernel and found https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=8a3e33cf92c7b7ae25c589eccd1a69ab11cc4353 as good candidate for causing this behavior. 

Can you test http://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=13119361 when it finishes?

We have a winner!
Bob@engineering ~$ uname -a
Linux engineering 4.4.2-301.removablefix.fc23.x86_64 #1 SMP Thu Feb 25 01:42:25 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
Bob@engineering ~$ 

solves the problem.

Observation. There appears to be long running problems with sata/esata internal/external system vs. mountable determinations according to many discussions on the web. One source mentions that only certain AHCI controller configurations (and only AHCI controllers) are even capable of setting appropriate mode bits. It has been suggested that special rules be applied to certain known hardware schemes to eliminate confusion.

FWIW, the computer configuration I'm using is an i7-920
GA-EX58-UD4P (rev. 1.0)
Intel® X58 + ICH10R Chipset

AHCI configuration of course, and originally (but not now) running raid0 on the jmicron controller. (There was much testing with Hans de Goede back then which requires him to perform extensive code rewrites.)

There is an e-sata port installed (an expansion slot extension of the internal ports) but not being currently used.

It seems that the Serial ATA AHCI 1.3.1 Specification is the latest version.

http://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/io/serial-ata/serial-ata-ahci-spec-rev1-3-1.html

For the Dell initial boot problem, might something have changed regarding the handling of the BIOS/OS Handoff Mechanism documented in section 10.6 page 108 of the spec? If I understand the failure symptom being reported--flashing disk light right at initial boot attempt--it might possibly be happening due to a broken handoff. This would be a different problem than an improper automount ala a usb stick.

(In reply to Madi from comment #52)
> (In reply to Fedora Update System from comment #51)
> > kernel-4.4.3-300.fc23 has been pushed to the Fedora 23 stable repository. If
> > problems still persist, please make note of it in this bug report.
> 
> Bug still persists.
> F23 on Intel Xeon E3, LSI SAS controller. 4.4.* are problematic (no disks
> detected). Other kernel's up to 4.3.5 where running perfectly. What other
> info should i deliver?

Your issue is likely entirely different than the one this bug covers.  The 4.4 kernel uses mpt3sas.ko for some SAS cards now instead of mpt2sas.ko.  The appropriate modalias is in the mpt3sas driver, but dracut isn't picking it up when it creates the initramfs.  You will need to rebuild your initramfs and explicitly tell dracut to use mpt3sas.  This issue is being tracked in bug 1313025

bugs.title: CVE-2016-2550 kernel: incorrectly accounted in-flight fds

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2016-2550 kernel: incorrectly accounted in-flight fds

long_desc.thetext:
The fix for CVE-2013-4312 incorrectly accounted the
number of in-flight fds over a unix domain socket to the original
opener of the file-descriptor. This allows another process to
arbitrary deplete the original file-openers resource limit for the
maximum of open files.

CVE-ID request and assignment:

http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/401
http://seclists.org/oss-sec/2016/q1/412

Upstream patch:

https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=415e3d3e90ce9e18727e8843ae343eda5a58fad6

Commit, which introduced the issue (it was addressing CVE-2013-4312):

https://git.kernel.org/cgit/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=712f4aad406bb1ed67f3f98d04c044191f0ff593

This issue does not affect the Linux kernel packages as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, 7 and MRG-2.
